Below is a simple high-level algorithmic template (in pseudocode) for addressing “jailbreak” attempts (i.e., adversarial prompts designed to subvert an LLM’s alignment or guardrails). This outline integrates ideas discussed across the listed references—such as perplexity-based detection, sequential monitoring, multi-modal injection checks, and universal jailbreaking strategies—to highlight how one might systematically process input, detect potential jailbreak content, and produce aligned outputs.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
COMPUTATIONAL PROBLEM: #A1. Jailbreak
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

References (contextual inspirations):
• [HauntAttack: When Attack Follows Reasoning as a Shadow (2025)]  
• [Beyond Jailbreaks: Revealing Stealthier and Broader LLM Security Risks (2025)]  
• [From Threat to Tool: Leveraging Refusal-Aware Injection Attacks (2025)]  
• [LLMs Caught in the Crossfire: Malware Requests and Jailbreak Challenges (2025)]  
• [SoK: Evaluating Jailbreak Guardrails for Large Language Models (2025)]  
• [Monitoring Decomposition Attacks in LLMs (2025)]  
• [Con Instruction: Universal Jailbreaking of Multimodal LLMs (2025)]  
• [Align is not Enough: Multimodal Universal Jailbreak Attack (2025)]  
• [ReGA: Representation-Guided Abstraction for Model-based Safeguarding of LLMs (2025)]  
• [BitBypass: A New Direction in Jailbreaking Aligned LLMs (2025)]  
• [An Interpretable N-gram Perplexity Threat Model for Large Language Model Jailbreaks (2025)]  
• [USB: A Comprehensive and Unified Safety Evaluation Benchmark for Multimodal LLMs (2025)]  
• [GeneBreaker: Jailbreak Attacks against DNA Language Models (2025)]  
• [What Really Matters in Many-Shot Attacks? (2025)]

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
ALGORITHMIC APPROACH
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Assume we have:
• A large language model LLM with safety/alignment constraints.  
• A detection component DETECT (e.g., perplexity-based, representation-based, or rule-based).  
• A safe generation component SAFE_GEN that enforces or re-checks alignment pre- and post-response.  

Pseudocode:

1. Initialize Parameters  
   1.1. Load or set up the LLM (including any alignment constraints).  
   1.2. Initialize the detection subsystem DETECT (e.g., n-gram perplexity model, anomaly scoring, or sequential monitors as discussed in “Monitoring Decomposition Attacks…”).  
   1.3. (Optional) Configure a “message policy” or “response policy” for how to handle borderline or high-risk prompts.  

2. Process Input Data  
   2.1. Receive user’s request prompt p.  
   2.2. Evaluate p by passing it to DETECT.  
       • DETECT(p) computes a “jailbreak risk” score.  
         – May include:  
           ○ Perplexity-based detection (cf. “An Interpretable N-gram Perplexity Threat Model…”).  
           ○ Representation-based analysis (cf. “ReGA: Representation-Guided Abstraction…”).  
           ○ Heuristic or rule-based checks for known injection cues.  
           ○ Multi-modal scanning if p contains additional modalities (cf. “Con Instruction…, Align is Not Enough…”).  
         – Output: risk_score ∈ [0,1], threshold T.  
   2.3. If risk_score > T, label p as a potential jailbreak attempt. Otherwise, label it as safe.  

3. Generate Output  
   3.1. If p is labeled as safe:  
       • Directly use LLM to generate a response, R = LLM(p).  
       • (Optional) Run the generated response R through SAFE_GEN or a “refusal-aware” re-check (cf. “From Threat to Tool…”).  
       • Final response = R.  

   3.2. If p is labeled as a jailbreak attempt:  
       • Attempt partial rewriting or “aligned generation”:  
         – Example approach: R = SAFE_GEN(LLM, p), ensuring no violation of policy.  
         – This can include refusal, safe completion, or partial answer with redaction.  
       • E.g., if the prompt is trying to circumvent guardrails, produce a refusal or provide partial information that does not breach alignment.  
       • Final response = R (aligned or refused).  

Pseudo-Implementation (Sketch):

   function HANDLE_PROMPT(p):
       risk_score = DETECT(p)
       if risk_score > T:
           # High risk of jailbreak
           return REFUSE_OR_SAFE_GEN(p)
       else:
           raw_response = LLM(p)
           # Optional final pass to check outgoing response
           final_response = SAFE_GEN(raw_response)
           return final_response

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
COMPLEXITY ANALYSIS
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

• Time Complexity: O(n)  
  – Let n be the number of tokens in the prompt p.  
  – The detection subsystem often inspects each token or n-gram to compute perplexity/risk scores.  
  – Response generation is also O(n) in the token-by-token decode loop for typical large language model inference.  

• Space Complexity: O(1)  
  – The approach can be implemented with constant additional memory, aside from the memory used by the LLM’s fixed parameters.  
  – The detection or risk scoring can maintain only a small set of running statistics (e.g., local state for perplexity or counters for n-grams).  

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
HOW IT CONNECTS TO THE REFERENCES
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

• Perplexity-based Jailbreak Detection (“An Interpretable N-gram Perplexity Threat Model…”)  
• Multi-modal Attack Vectors and Universal Jailbreaks (“Con Instruction…”, “Align is not Enough…”)  
• Refusal-Aware Strategies (“From Threat to Tool…”), including how to alter or intercept the LLM’s partial responses.  
• Lightweight Sequential Monitors for step-by-step reasoning (“Monitoring Decomposition Attacks…”).  
• Representation-Guided Checks and Abstraction (“ReGA…”).  
• Many-Shot Attack Vulnerabilities (“What Really Matters in Many-Shot Attacks?”).  

By combining these ideas, the algorithm above aims to maintain alignment in the face of diverse jailbreaking strategies—while respecting typical computational constraints of O(n) time and O(1) extra space.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
END

azure-gpt-45.response:
Below is a structured and detailed computational problem description for the provided research topic:

---

## Computational Problem: Jailbreaking Large Language Models (LLMs)

### Problem Description:
Jailbreaking refers to a type of adversarial attack against Large Language Models (LLMs) and multimodal LLMs (MLLMs), where an attacker attempts to bypass or circumvent the model's safety and alignment guardrails. The primary goal of these jailbreak attacks is to make the model generate content it has explicitly been designed to refuse or avoid due to ethical, safety, or policy-related reasons.

### Inputs:
- \( M \): A target LLM or multimodal LLM model, which takes as input a textual, multimodal, or structured prompt and outputs a textual response.
- \( G \): A set of alignment and security guardrails implemented in model \( M \) to prevent unsafe, harmful, or policy-violating outputs.
- \( x \): An initial query or prompt that requests output explicitly prohibited by the implemented guardrails \( G \).
- \( A \): A jailbreak technique or adversarial input crafting methodology (e.g., textual injection, non-textual modality injection, bitstream camouflage, decomposition attack, multimodal universal jailbreak strategy).

### Output:
- A modified query \( x' \) derived from the original prompt \( x \) using the jailbreak technique \( A \).
- The response \( y' \) generated by the target model \( M \) after processing the adversarial prompt \( x' \).

### Objective:
The adversary’s goal is to find a query \( x' \) such that:
- \( x' = A(x) \) (i.e., generated by applying a jailbreak attack method \( A \)).
- \( y' \) (the model response to \( x' \)) violates the guardrails \( G \) and successfully generates unsafe, harmful, or prohibited content.

### Evaluation Metrics:
The effectiveness of jailbreak attacks can be evaluated with the following metrics:
- **Success Rate**: The proportion of adversarial prompts \( x' \) that successfully bypass model safety guardrails \( G \).
- **Stealthiness**: How difficult it is for standard detection mechanisms, including humans and automated safety monitors, to identify the adversarial nature of \( x' \).
- **Generalizability**: The method’s effectiveness across different models, modalities, and safety alignment setups.
- **Efficiency**: Computational resources and query overhead required to generate effective jailbreak queries.

### Computational Constraints:
- **Time Complexity**: \(O(n)\), linear in the length or complexity of the input prompt.
- **Space Complexity**: \(O(1)\), constant additional memory beyond input/output data.

### Algorithmic Approach:
To implement and evaluate jailbreak attacks, the following algorithmic steps are typically employed:

1. **Initialization**:
   - Select a target model \( M \) and guardrails \( G \).
   - Obtain an initial prohibited query \( x \) clearly rejected by the model.
   - Set up the jailbreak attack method \( A \).

2. **Input Processing**:
   - Apply attack technique \( A \) to the input \( x \) to produce the adversarial prompt \( x' \):
     \[
     x' \leftarrow A(x)
     \]

3. **Output Generation**:
   - Query the model \( M \) with the adversarial prompt \( x' \):
     \[
     y' \leftarrow M(x')
     \]

4. **Verification**:
   - Check if the generated output \( y' \) violates the implemented guardrails \( G \).

5. **Measurement and Analysis**:
   - Collect metrics (success rate, stealthiness, generalizability, efficiency).
   - Analyze model vulnerabilities and effectiveness of jailbreak guardrails.

### Example Use Cases (Inspired by Provided Papers):
- **Textual Injection Attacks**: Injecting carefully crafted strings or sequences that bypass guardrails based on perplexity or other statistical measures ([Interpretable N-gram Perplexity Threat Model](https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.16222)).
- **Multimodal Injection Attacks**: Leveraging non-textual modalities (images, audio, bitstreams) to universally jailbreak multimodal LLMs ([Con Instruction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.00548), [BitBypass](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.02479)).
- **Refusal-Aware Injection**: Leveraging insights from model refusals to efficiently craft adversarial prompts ([From Threat to Tool](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.10020)).
- **Decomposition Attacks**: Breaking down instructions into multiple seemingly innocuous steps that collectively bypass guardrails ([Monitoring Decomposition Attacks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.10949)).
- **Pathogenicity Guidance in DNA Models**: Jailbreaking DNA language models to generate potentially harmful biological sequences ([GeneBreaker](https://arxiv.org/abs/2505.23839)).

---

This computational problem formulation clearly defines the inputs, outputs, objectives, evaluation metrics, computational constraints, and algorithmic approach, providing a comprehensive framework for addressing jailbreak attacks in large language models.

Here’s a concise summary of the papers listed in A1. Jailbreak, with a focus on recent developments (mid-2025) in LLM jailbreak, security risks, and alignment:

1. HauntAttack: When Attack Follows Reasoning as a Shadow (2025/06)
 Explores how sophisticated attacks can “shadow” LLM reasoning processes, making jailbreaks harder to detect and prevent.

2. Beyond Jailbreaks: Revealing Stealthier and Broader LLM Security Risks Stemming from Alignment Failures (2025/06)
 Unveils new categories of security risk in LLMs beyond traditional jailbreaks, focusing on subtle alignment failures.

3. From Threat to Tool: Leveraging Refusal-Aware Injection Attacks for Safety Alignment (2025/06)
 Investigates how adversarial attacks that exploit model refusals can be repurposed to strengthen LLM safety alignment.

4. LLMs Caught in the Crossfire: Malware Requests and Jailbreak Challenges (2025/06, ACL’25)
 Analyzes how LLMs handle malware-related queries and the dual challenge of avoiding harmful outputs while not over-blocking benign requests.

5. SoK: Evaluating Jailbreak Guardrails for Large Language Models (2025/06)
 A systematization of knowledge (SoK) paper reviewing the effectiveness of current guardrails and defenses against LLM jailbreaks.

6. Monitoring Decomposition Attacks in LLMs with Lightweight Sequential Monitors (2025/06)
 Proposes efficient monitoring strategies to detect “decomposition attacks” that sequentially bypass LLM safeguards.

7. Con Instruction: Universal Jailbreaking of Multimodal Large Language Models via Non-Textual Modalities (2025/06)
 Demonstrates multimodal jailbreaks that exploit image, audio, or other non-textual inputs to bypass LLM safety filters.

8. Align is not Enough: Multimodal Universal Jailbreak Attack against Multimodal Large Language Models (2025/06)
 Shows that even aligned multimodal LLMs remain vulnerable to universal jailbreaks exploiting cross-modal weaknesses.

9. ReGA: Representation-Guided Abstraction for Model-based Safeguarding of LLMs (2025/06)
 Presents a novel defense technique (ReGA) leveraging model representations to improve LLM safety against jailbreaks.

10. BitBypass: A New Direction in Jailbreaking Aligned Large Language Models with Bitstream Camouflage (2025/06)
 Explores the use of encoded bitstreams (e.g., binary or compressed data) to hide jailbreak prompts from LLM filters.

11. An Interpretable N-gram Perplexity Threat Model for Large Language Model Jailbreaks (2025/05)
 Proposes a threat model using n-gram perplexity as an interpretable metric to identify and assess jailbreak attempts.

12. USB: A Comprehensive and Unified Safety Evaluation Benchmark for Multimodal Large Language Models (2025/05)
 Introduces a new benchmark for evaluating multimodal LLM safety and vulnerability to jailbreaks.

13. GeneBreaker: Jailbreak Attacks against DNA Language Models with Pathogenicity Guidance (2025/05)
 Investigates jailbreak attacks specifically targeting DNA-based language models, with implications for biosecurity.

14. What Really Matters in Many-Shot Attacks? An Empirical Study of Long-Context Vulnerabilities in LLMs (2025/05)
 Analyzes how increasing context length (many-shot prompting) affects LLM vulnerability to jailbreak or misuse.

Trends and Takeaways:

- Jailbreak methods are evolving: attacks now target multimodal inputs, long contexts, and employ encoding tricks.
- Defenses are advancing: new monitoring, abstraction-based, and benchmark-driven approaches are being developed.
- Alignment remains brittle: even aligned LLMs can be bypassed via novel or cross-modal attacks.
- Security research is expanding into specialized domains, e.g., DNA language models.

azure-o1.response:
Below is a concise overview of the listed papers, each focusing on recent research into jailbreaking, alignment vulnerabilities, and safety guardrails for large language models (LLMs). While the exact details and methodologies can only be inferred from the titles and abstracts (where available), these summaries encapsulate the main themes and contributions as indicated by the provided metadata.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) HauntAttack: When Attack Follows Reasoning as a Shadow
   • Citation: [arXiv:2506.07031, 2025/06]
   • Focus: Investigates an attack (“HauntAttack”) that exploits the reasoning steps within an LLM’s chain-of-thought. Suggests that once an initial vulnerability is found, attempts at aligning or silencing malicious reasoning may still leave residues (the “shadow”), creating chains of attack that follow the model’s reasoning process.

2) Beyond Jailbreaks: Revealing Stealthier and Broader LLM Security Risks Stemming from Alignment Failures
   • Citation: [arXiv:2506.07402, 2025/06]
   • Focus: Examines more subtle, stealthy ways in which alignment failures can manifest as security risks. The emphasis is not only on “jailbreaks” but on less obvious vulnerabilities that can remain hidden and spread across multiple LLM applications.

3) From Threat to Tool: Leveraging Refusal-Aware Injection Attacks for Safety Alignment
   • Citation: [arXiv:2506.10020, 2025/06]
   • Focus: Proposes “refusal-aware injection attacks” as both a demonstration of vulnerabilities and a means to refine safety alignment. By deliberately triggering or simulating these attacks, the paper aims to improve real-world detection and mitigation strategies for LLMs.

4) LLMs Caught in the Crossfire: Malware Requests and Jailbreak Challenges
   • Citation: [arXiv:2506.10022, ACL’25, 2025/06]
   • Focus: Explores the landscape of malicious usage: when LLMs are asked to aid in generating or analyzing malware-like content. Investigates how existing jailbreaking methods complicate detection and how LLMs might be hardened against such misuse.

5) SoK: Evaluating Jailbreak Guardrails for Large Language Models
   • Citation: [arXiv:2506.10597, 2025/06]
   • Focus: A “Systematization of Knowledge (SoK)” paper formally categorizing and evaluating current “jailbreak guardrails.” Provides a comprehensive review of techniques for protecting LLMs from malicious prompts and systematically benchmarks their effectiveness.

6) Monitoring Decomposition Attacks in LLMs with Lightweight Sequential Monitors
   • Citation: [arXiv:2506.10949, 2025/06]
   • Focus: Investigates “decomposition attacks”—likely a scenario where multiple partial prompts combine to bypass safety checks. Proposes a lightweight monitoring method targeting an LLM’s sequential outputs, aiming to thwart these combined or multi-step exploits.

7) Con Instruction: Universal Jailbreaking of Multimodal Large Language Models via Non-Textual Modalities
   • Citation: [arXiv:2506.00548, 2025/06]
   • Focus: Extends jailbreak vulnerabilities beyond purely textual instructions and into multimodal channels (e.g., images, audio). Demonstrates how users can insert “con instructions” across different modalities to circumvent LLM guardrails or alignment filters.

8) Align is not Enough: Multimodal Universal Jailbreak Attack against Multimodal Large Language Models
   • Citation: [arXiv:2506.01307, 2025/06]
   • Focus: Similar to the above paper, but with an emphasis on the insufficiency of standard alignment in multimodal LLMs. Shows how purely text-based alignment strategies can fail when images, graphics, or other data types are used to encode malicious instructions.

9) ReGA: Representation-Guided Abstraction for Model-based Safeguarding of LLMs
   • Citation: [arXiv:2506.01770, 2025/06]
   • Focus: Introduces a “Representation-Guided Abstraction” (ReGA) approach. Potentially uses the internal representation space of an LLM to detect or thwart jailbreak attempts, focusing on how an LLM internally abstracts instructions and context.

10) BitBypass: A New Direction in Jailbreaking Aligned Large Language Models with Bitstream Camouflage
    • Citation: [arXiv:2506.02479, 2025/06]
    • Focus: Explores an innovative jailbreak method that implants instructions at the bitstream level. This “camouflage” suggests malicious content could be hidden in data streams or encoded forms to escape standard content filters.

11) An Interpretable N-gram Perplexity Threat Model for Large Language Model Jailbreaks
    • Citation: [arXiv:2410.16222, 2025/05]
    • Focus: Uses n-gram perplexity to analyze or detect potential jailbreak prompts. The interpretable nature suggests a robust approach for explaining how or why a given prompt might lead to a jailbreak, focusing on classical language-modeling metrics.

12) USB: A Comprehensive and Unified Safety Evaluation Benchmark for Multimodal Large Language Models
    • Citation: [arXiv:2505.23793, 2025/05]
    • Focus: Proposes a large-scale benchmark (“USB”) to evaluate safety aspects across multimodal LLMs. Provides a standardized, wide-ranging test set to probe vulnerabilities, alignment, and content-filtering methods in both text and non-text scenarios.

13) GeneBreaker: Jailbreak Attacks against DNA Language Models with Pathogenicity Guidance
    • Citation: [arXiv:2505.23839, 2025/05]
    • Focus: Extends the concept of jailbreaking to specialized “DNA language models” used in genomics. “Pathogenicity guidance” presumably indicates methods for manipulating models that generate or classify DNA sequences, underscoring the broader impact of jailbreaking outside typical text-based LLMs.

14) What Really Matters in Many-Shot Attacks? An Empirical Study of Long-Context Vulnerabilities in LLMs
    • Citation: [arXiv:2505.19773, 2025/05]
    • Focus: Investigates the role of context length in many-shot prompts. Discusses how extended context windows might amplify or obscure certain jailbreak methods and offers empirical findings on which aspects of context are more (or less) susceptible to adversarial usage.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Summary of Common Themes
• Many of these papers focus on emerging techniques for jailbreaking, showing that “traditional” text-only alignment approaches can be bypassed by sophisticated or multimodal prompts.  
• Several papers highlight how boundaries between safe usage and misuse can blur when LLMs are given large or chained contexts (e.g., “decomposition attacks”) or specialized domains (e.g., DNA language models).  
• Proposed solutions or frameworks range from more advanced monitoring systems and perplexity-based threat models to representation-level safeguarding techniques, all aiming to maintain user safety and alignment while mitigating newly discovered vulnerabilities.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
If you need further details—such as a deeper discussion of a specific paper’s methodology, potential real-world implications of these jailbreak techniques, or comparisons between different proposed guardrails—feel free to let me know!

- **Long-context vulnerabilities** are being exploited through many-shot attacks
- **Alignment failures** are revealed to cause broader security risks beyond traditional jailbreaks
- **Refusal-aware injection attacks** are being studied for potential safety alignment improvements
- **Universal jailbreaking techniques** for multimodal LLMs demonstrate cross-modality vulnerabilities

azure-gpt-4.response:
# Task Processing

This repository provides a processor for extracting and structuring paper metadata from a markdown-formatted list, such as:

```
# A1. Jailbreak
- [2025/06] **[HauntAttack: When Attack Follows Reasoning as a Shadow](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.07031)** ![LLM](https://img.shields.io/badge/LLM-589cf4)
- [2025/06] **[Beyond Jailbreaks: Revealing Stealthier and Broader LLM Security Risks Stemming from Alignment Failures](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.07402)** ![LLM](https://img.shields.io/badge/LLM-589cf4)
...
```

## Approach

The processor works in three steps:

### 1. Validate Input

- Ensures the input is non-empty.
- Checks the input follows the expected markdown paper-list format.

### 2. Execute Processing

- Parses each line to extract:
  - Publication date (e.g., `[2025/06]`)
  - Paper title and arXiv URL
  - Tags (from badges, e.g., `LLM`, `VLM`, `Benchmark`, etc.)
  - Conference info (if present, e.g., `ACL'25`)
- Converts the markdown to a structured output (such as JSON or CSV).

### 3. Return Result

- Outputs the extracted data in a machine-friendly format (JSON by default).

---

## Example Usage

```bash
./processor "# A1. Jailbreak
- [2025/06] **[HauntAttack: When Attack Follows Reasoning as a Shadow](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.07031)** ![LLM](https://img.shields.io/badge/LLM-589cf4)
- [2025/06] **[Beyond Jailbreaks: Revealing Stealthier and Broader LLM Security Risks Stemming from Alignment Failures](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.07402)** ![LLM](https://img.shields.io/badge/LLM-589cf4)
- [2025/06] **[From Threat to Tool: Leveraging Refusal-Aware Injection Attacks for Safety Alignment](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.10020)** ![LLM](https://img.shields.io/badge/LLM-589cf4)
- [2025/06] **[LLMs Caught in the Crossfire: Malware Requests and Jailbreak Challenges ](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.10022)** ![LLM](https://img.shields.io/badge/LLM-589cf4) ![ACL'25](https://img.shields.io/badge/ACL'25-f1b800)
- [2025/06] **[SoK: Evaluating Jailbreak Guardrails for Large Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.10597)** ![LLM](https://img.shields.io/badge/LLM-589cf4)
..."
```

**Output Example:**

```json
[
  {
    "date": "2025/06",
    "title": "HauntAttack: When Attack Follows Reasoning as a Shadow",
    "url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.07031",
    "tags": ["LLM"]
  },
  {
    "date": "2025/06",
    "title": "LLMs Caught in the Crossfire: Malware Requests and Jailbreak Challenges",
    "url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.10022",
    "tags": ["LLM", "ACL'25"]
  }
  // ...
]
```

---

## Notes

- The processor expects each paper as a single markdown list item.
- Tags are extracted from badge alt-texts.
- Conference/journal info may be included as tags.
- Input can be piped or passed as a string argument.

---

## Requirements

- Python 3.x (if using the provided Python script)
- No external dependencies

---

## License

MIT

---

## Contact

For questions or contributions, please open an issue or pull request.

```python
def process_request(request):
    """
    Process a request and return the result.
    
    Args:
        request (str): The request to be processed.
    
    Returns:
        str: The result of the processing.
    """
    # 1. Validate input
    if not isinstance(request, str) or not request.strip():
        return "Invalid input: request must be a non-empty string."
    
    # 2. Execute processing
    result = "Processing request:\n\n" + request + "\n\nResult:"
    
    # 3. Return result
    return result
```

claude-4-opus.response:
I'll help you create a REST API endpoint specification for the `/api/v1/requests` endpoint based on the example you've provided.

## REST API Endpoint Documentation

### POST /api/v1/requests

Creates a new request for processing tasks.

#### Request

**URL:** `/api/v1/requests`  
**Method:** `POST`  
**Content-Type:** `application/json`

##### Request Headers
```
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token} (if authentication is required)
```

##### Request Body Schema

| Field | Type | Required | Description |
|-------|------|----------|-------------|
| `task` | string | Yes | The task content to be processed. Can include markdown formatting, links, and structured data. |
| `priority` | string | No | Priority level for the request. Valid values: `"low"`, `"normal"`, `"high"`. Default: `"normal"` |
| `async` | boolean | No | Whether the request should be processed asynchronously. Default: `false` |

##### Example Request Body
```json
{
  "task": "# A1. Jailbreak\n- [2025/06] **[HauntAttack: When Attack Follows Reasoning as a Shadow](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.07031)** ![LLM](https://img.shields.io/badge/LLM-589cf4)\n...",
  "priority": "normal",
  "async": false
}
```

#### Response

##### Success Response

**Status Code:** `200 OK`

**Response Body Schema:**

| Field | Type | Description |
|-------|------|-------------|
| `status` | string | Processing status. Possible values: `"processed"`, `"queued"`, `"failed"` |
| `id` | string | Unique identifier for the request |

**Example Response:**
```json
{
  "status": "processed",
  "id": "req-123"
}
```

##### Error Responses

**400 Bad Request**
```json
{
  "error": "Invalid request body",
  "message": "The 'task' field is required"
}
```

**401 Unauthorized**
```json
{
  "error": "Unauthorized",
  "message": "Invalid or missing authentication token"
}
```

**500 Internal Server Error**
```json
{
  "error": "Internal server error",
  "message": "An unexpected error occurred while processing the request"
}
```

azure-gpt-4.response:
You are using a very long and complex regex intended to strictly validate a specific Markdown block with links, badges, and references, but the regex is almost certainly not matching as you expect. Let's break down the issues and how to approach this:

## Issues with Your Regex

1. **Overuse of Character Classes**:  
   `[aA][tT][tT][aA][cC][kK]` is used everywhere. This is unnecessary for case-insensitive matching; `/gi` already makes the match case-insensitive.
2. **Square Brackets for Numbers**:  
   `[22][00][22][55]` does **not** match the string `220255`; it matches one character from `2` or `2`, then one from `0` or `0`, etc. You want `220255`, so just write `220255`.
3. **Escaping**:  
   You are escaping every `-`, which is not needed outside character classes.
4. **Line Breaks**:  
   If your input contains real line breaks, you need to handle them with `\s*` or `[\s\S]*`.  
   If it is all one line, just use `\s+` for whitespace.
5. **Overall Complexity**:  
   Such a huge regex is unmaintainable and error-prone. You should either break it up, or switch to a parser.
6. **Regex Length Limits**:  
   Some engines (especially browsers) will fail or be very slow with a regex this long.

## What Your Regex Should Look Like

- Use the `/gi` flag for case-insensitivity.
- Write actual words, not `[jJ][aA][iI][lL][bB][rR][eE][aA][kK]`.
- Write actual numbers, not `[2][2][0][0][2][2][5][5]`.

### Example

Suppose you want to match this block (simplified):

```
# A1. Jailbreak - [2022/06] **[Hauntattack: When attack follows reasoning as a shadow](https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.0073)** ![llm](https://img.shields.io/badge/llm-589cf4)
- [2022/06] **[Beyond Jailbreaks: ...](https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.0074)** ![llm](https://img.shields.io/badge/llm-589cf4)
```

A **better regex** (for a single line) would be:

```js
const regex = /^#\s+A1\.\s+Jailbreak\s*-\s*\[2022\/06\]\s+\*\*\[Hauntattack\: When attack follows reasoning as a shadow\]\(https:\/\/arxiv\.org\/abs\/2206\.0073\)\*\*\s+!\[llm\]\(https:\/\/img\.shields\.io\/badge\/llm\-589cf4\)/i;
```

If you want to validate the **entire block**, you should use multiline mode and possibly `[\s\S]*`:

```js
const regex = /^#\s+A1\.\s+Jailbreak[\s\S]*?\[2206\.0073\)[\s\S]*?!\[llm\]\(https:\/\/img\.shields\.io\/badge\/llm\-589cf4\)[\s\S]*?\-\s+\[2022\/06\]/i;
```

Or, to match the whole block more loosely:

```js
const regex = /^#\s+A1\.\s+Jailbreak[\s\S]+?\[Hauntattack: When attack follows reasoning as a shadow\]\(https:\/\/arxiv\.org\/abs\/2206\.0073\)[\s\S]+?!\[llm\]\(https:\/\/img\.shields\.io\/badge\/llm\-589cf4\)[\s\S]+?$/i;
```

## How to Fix and Proceed

1. **Rewrite** your regex to use real words and numbers.
2. **Use the `i` flag** for case-insensitivity.
3. **Break up** your regex to check each section separately, or use a simple Markdown parser if possible.

### Example: Validating Each Line

```js
const lines = input.trim().split('\n');
if (
  /^#\s+A1\.\s+Jailbreak\s*-\s*\[2022\/06\]/i.test(lines[0]) &&
  /\[Hauntattack: When attack follows reasoning as a shadow\]\(https:\/\/arxiv\.org\/abs\/2206\.0073\)/i.test(lines[0]) &&
  /!\[llm\]\(https:\/\/img\.shields\.io\/badge\/llm\-589cf4\)/i.test(lines[0])
  // ... and so on for each expected line
) {
  processRequest(input);
} else {
  reject("Invalid format");
}
```

## Summary

- Your regex is **overly complex and incorrect** due to misuse of character classes.
- **Rewrite** it using normal words/numbers, and use `/i` for case-insensitive matching.
- Consider **breaking up** validation per line or section.
- For strict validation, use a **parser**, not a regex.

If you provide a **sample input** and clarify what you want to accept/reject, I can write an exact regex for your needs!

azure-o3-mini.response:
Below is an explanation of what’s happening in your code and some suggestions for improvement.

─────────────────────────────  
Overview of the Code

Your code is essentially doing this:

 if (input.match(<huge‐regex>)) {  
  processRequest(input);  
 } else {  
  reject("Invalid format");  
 }

That is, if the provided input fully matches your extremely detailed regular expression, you call processRequest(input). Otherwise, you “reject” the input with an error message.

─────────────────────────────  
What the Regular Expression Does

1. It begins with a literal hash sign (“#”) followed by at least one whitespace character (using \s+).  
2. Then—you might notice—there’s a pattern like [aA][11]\. which appears to try to match a token (perhaps “A11.” or something similar). In many places the regex “hard‐codes” characters using very explicit character classes. For example, to match “jailbreak” you wrote:  
  [jJ][aA][iI][lL][bB][rR][eE][aA][kK]  
 This pattern forces a letter‐by‐letter match but allows either an uppercase letter or a lowercase letter for each position.
3. After that you see segments like  
  \-\s+\[[22][00][22][55]\/[00][66]\]  
 which matches a literal dash, spaces, and then a bracketed group where it expects (for instance) “22 00 22 55/00 66.” (Note that [22] is a character set that will match a “2” — writing it twice is redundant. The same goes for things like [00] which only match “0”.)
4. There are then several sections that use **markers, additional square-bracket sections that contain more phrases (for example, “[hauntattacK: when att ack follows reason i n g as a shadow]” with every character specified in a case-insensitive way) and then a URL wrapped in parentheses.
5. This pattern continues throughout the regex. In total there are many segments separated by literal dashes (‑) and intervening whitespace. Each segment follows a very strict format that includes:
  • A header in square brackets that contains a descriptive phrase (like “beyond jailbreaks: revealing stealthier and broader llm security risks stemming from alignment failures”),
  • A URL inside parentheses,
  • A “bit” of markdown-like syntax (using ** for bold and ![…] for images or other markers).
6. At the end you see the “gi” flags; “g” to search globally (if you ever call match more than once) and “i” for case-insensitive matching.

─────────────────────────────  
Some Points to Consider

a. Redundancy with Case Matching:
  You’re explicitly matching both cases by writing [jJ] etc. While you have turned on the “i” (ignore case) flag at the end, that flag would make the pattern case‑insensitive anyway. In other words, writing [jJ] is not necessary; you could just write “j” (or “jailbreak”) and let the flag do its work.

b. Character Classes for Digits:
  You have patterns like [22] or [00]. For example, [22] means “match either ‘2’ (or ‘2’ again)” – which is equivalent to simply writing “2”. If you mean to match two digits then you might be thinking of “22” literally; in that case you don’t need the brackets. (Or if you intended to match “2” twice and get something like “22”, you may want to simply write “22”.)

c. Maintainability and Readability:
  The regex is extremely verbose. If you are certain that only an exact output (with every single blank, dash, punctuation, and number) should be accepted, then such a “hard‑coded” approach might be acceptable. However, if you ever need to allow slight variants, it might be easier to split the problem into smaller pieces or relax some parts of the expression.

─────────────────────────────  
What to Do Next

1. If your goal is to reject any input that does not exactly follow the format you’ve written, then this regex will check for an exact match.
2. You might consider simplifying the regex by taking advantage of the “i” flag instead of writing every character in a case‑sensitive way.
3. Double-check the parts where you use character classes for digits (e.g. [22] instead of “22”) to make sure they match your intention.
4. Testing: It is highly recommended to test the regex on several sample inputs using an online regex tester or within your JavaScript environment. Because of its length and detail, minor omissions (or extra whitespace) in the expected input format might cause the match to fail.

─────────────────────────────  
Conclusion

Your code validates that the input string exactly matches a very strict, pre‑defined format before processing it. This ensures that only inputs formatted precisely as expected (down to every space, dash, and exact character) get accepted.

If you need further help modifying or debugging a particular section of this regex, feel free to ask.
